body.p:
It is a singular fact that your form of
March 19 only reached me a few days ago, which accounts
for the inquiries which I made in a late letter & to which
you reply in yours of April 3d remarking that you had
previously answered me. Let that pass

My main object just now in addressing you is to
say that as soon as I hear from you of a day being
freed for the c? at New York I shall make final
arrangements for my departure passage. The secretary
of the congregation informed you immediately of my appoint
ment as the Delegate. I shall leave here so as to
be in NYork by the 11th proxo unless I hear that the day
has been postponed. I suppose the Occident of
the 1st will satisfy me that the convention will be held
& as soon as that is recd. I may start. In your
last No you talk of many delegates from the same
congregation. Of course each Congregation can only have
one vote & even as to delegates, if one congregation is
allowed too many, the delegates from some may not
get a chance to say a word. Look to this in time.

Respecting the inside furniture of the Synagogue
here, you can take your time & need not ?
to ship anything altho' what you may have sent
will be taken care of by Mr Touro till my return
Perhaps you may like me & see some of the

“fixings” & the longer certain good are kept out of
this climate (until they are used) the better. As regards
more money you had best write direct to Mr Touro at
once, as he is very slow & you can say that as you
presume I am absent starting you address him instead
of me. by the bye, say a word to him upon the importance
of this convention & the propriety of each congregation sending
a proper delegate so that whatever expenses may grow
out of the convention he may not think the means of
the congregation are squandered.

I hope to meet Mr. Gutheim this summer
perhaps at the convention or if I take the Sandusky
route north I may see him in Cincinnati

I am altogether undetermined which may I shall
go, perhaps direct to NY by steamship hence on the
21st inst or on the 1st proximo, be to Savannah by
mail & thence by steamer to NY or I may pass through
to Charleston & there take steam. My movements will depend
upon my time, & the company of my respectable delegates
that I may fall in with.

I do not know if it will scarcely be worth while
for you to answer this letter, but still as I shall not
in all probability leave here before 20th perhaps it will be as well
for you to do so in case you have anything to say of moment

If you wish to see me before we meet at the convention
write to me here as ever at once. I should like to have
talk with you in advance of any caucusing, but

I think we shall not differ much in our
notions about “Reforms”.

I hear that Mr. Nathan (the revd.) has
left St Thomas, & gone to Jamaica to settle
up his business with his brother in law with
whom he was in partnership & that he (Nathan)
will not return to St Thomas. What's in the wind?
I have recd no letters from him for a long time past.
We continue to worship regularly in the rooms temporarily
prepared & have an excellent “Siphar” tho' small
which we can keep as long as I please.

Between ourselves I doubt if the few who attend service
will continue after I leave here. If the yellow
fever is not prevalent in the summer I would like
to return & consecrate the synagogue for the New Year.
Of this more anon.

Hoping that you may enjoy our approaching
festival & be well to perform all your duties at the
convention

Will you be kind enough to offer my fondest
love to my dear Aunt & husband & tell them
that I hope to visit them for a day or so ere very
long, as I have concluded to order the chandelier bracket &c for
the gas to be used in the Synagogue, from your city & shall desire to explain to
Mr Cornelius precisely what I want.
